"Gullfoss Waterfall: A Majestic Icelandic Wonder"

"Where Nature Roars and Rainbows Bloom"



Wander Way
Home Trips Shop Contact Blog login profile

Gullfoss, one of Iceland's most famous waterfalls, is located in the southwest of the country, part of the Golden Circle route. The waterfall, whose name translates to "Golden Falls" in Icelandic, is found in the Hvítá river, which originates from the Langjökull glacier. The river's waters cascade down two stages into a deep canyon, creating an impressive and powerful sight that attracts visitors from around the world. With a height of 32 meters and a width of 70 meters, Gullfoss is truly a natural wonder of Iceland.


The falls are unique in that they take a dramatic two-step plunge—first, the water drops 11 meters and then 21 meters into the canyon below. This creates a mesmerizing visual effect, especially on sunny days, when the mist rising from the falls often forms rainbows, adding to the beauty of the scene. The falls are surrounded by rough, rocky terrain, making the viewpoint a thrilling location for tourists to stand and admire the power of nature.


Gullfoss also has an important place in Icelandic history. In the early 20th century, there were plans to harness the falls for hydroelectric power, but this idea was fiercely opposed by Icelanders, notably by Sigríður Tómasdóttir, the daughter of a local farmer. Her determined efforts to save the waterfall from being dammed helped protect the falls as a national treasure. Today, Gullfoss remains a protected natural site, and visitors can explore the surrounding area, including walking paths and viewing platforms, making it a must-see destination for nature lovers and adventurers in Iceland.
